QuizName: Can You Finish These Lyrics From Taylor Swift's Reputation Album?
QuizTags: taylor swift, lyrics quiz, music, song quiz

QuestionName: It was the best of times, the worst of crimes...
1: ...late nights in the middle of June
2: ...it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness
3: ...I struck a match and blew your mind
4: ...cause nothing good starts in a getaway car
Lesson: Taylor uses a Charles Dickens quote—"It was the best of times, it was the worst of times" but substitutes 'times' for 'crimes', alluding to the conflict in her romantic life at the time. She's having a good time, but at the same time feels guilt because her happiness comes at the expense of someone else's.

QuestionName: I can feel the flames on my skin, crimson red paint on my lips...
1: ...If a man talks shit, then I owe him nothing
2: ...I've been Miss Misery since your goodbye
3: ...But if he drops my name, then I owe him nothin'
Lesson: Taylor has an affinity for red lipstick — in addition to being her signature look, she mentions it on tracks including 2014's "Blank Space", "Style", and "Wildest Dreams", as well as the earlier reputation track "End Game".

QuestionName: Change my priorities. The taste of your lips is my idea of luxury...
1: ...Salute to me, I'm the American Dream
2: ...Is this the end of all the endings? My broken bones are mending
4: ...Salute to me, I'm your American Queen
Lesson: Joe Alwyn, Taylor's boyfriend at the time, is from England, a country ruled by a monarch.

QuestionName: Whisky on ice, Sunset and Vine...
1: ...I knew it from the first old fashioned, we were cursed.
2: ...I feel like I might sink and drown and die
3: ...You've ruined my life by not being mine
4: ...You make me so happy it turns back to sad
Lesson: "Sunset and Vine" is a famous intersection between Sunset Boulevard and Vine Street in downtown Hollywood. The combination of whiskey and Hollywood implies the high-flying lifestyle of the rich and famous.

QuestionName: "I'm sorry, the old Taylor can't come to the phone right now....
2: ...And we are never getting back together. Like, ever."
3: ...Honey, I rose up from the dead, I do it all the time
4: ...But I got smarter, I got harder in the nick of time
Lesson: "Look What You Made Me Do" is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift. It was released on August 24, 2017, by Big Machine Records, as the lead single from her sixth studio album, Reputation (2017).

QuestionName: I don't want you like a best friend...
2: ....Only bought this dress so you could take it off
3: ...Flashback when you met me/Your buzzcut and my hair bleached
4: ...You made your mark on me, golden tattoo
Lesson: "Dress" is one of Taylor's most sexually charged songs on the album, and a sonically slow steamy ballad. The song details Taylor's wants and lusts over another lover. As the name implies, many of the sexual references throughout the song pertain to dresses.

QuestionName: This ain't for the best, my reputation's never been worse, so...
3: ...you and me, we'd be a big conversation
4: ...is it cool that I said all that?
Lesson: Much like "Gorgeous", "Delicate" sees Taylor taking a more hesitant approach while pursuing a new man. Sonically, the record utilizes chilling voice harmonies backed by a simple instrumental.

1: ...ladies and gentlemen, will you please stand
2: ...at least I did one thing right
3: ...he built a fire just to keep me warm
4: ...makin' forts under covers, trust him like a brother
Lesson: In 2019, Taylor reflected on songs like "Call It What You Want" from her album "reputation" as the ones that told the true love story of her relationship.

QuestionName: Here's a toast to my real friends...
1: ...They don't care about the he-said, she-said
2: ...He ain't reading what they call me lately
3: ...Had to listen to all this drama
4: ...'Cause forgiveness is a nice thing to do
Lesson: On this lighthearted, anthemic, and almost comical track Taylor Swift throws some major shade at all the haters.

QuestionName: I'll be there if you're the toast of the town, babe...
1: ...But I'll be cleaning up bottles with you on New Year's Day
2: ...But I stay when it's hard or it's wrong or we're making mistakes
3: ...Or if you strike out and you're crawling home
4: ...Hold on to the memories, they will hold on to you
Lesson: The closing track on reputation uses a New Year's party as a metaphor to discuss holding on to people and memories from both good and bad times.
